channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Yes, 'World's Largest Nerf Gun' Is An Actual World Record. This Engineer Made It
item.description: January 22, 2017 • Mark Rober designed a huge Nerf gun to win an office Nerf war. He talks to NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro about how he designed it, and what happens when you get hit with a pool noodle at 40 mph. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/22/511048797/yes-worlds-largest-nerf-gun-is-an-actual-world-record-this-engineer-made-it

item.title: How To Use Math To Pick A Favorite Football Team
item.description: January 22, 2017 • If your team leaves town, don't cry. Just pick a new team to root for. NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro speaks to FiveThirtyEight's Blythe Terrell about the math analysis that led her to find her new team. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/22/511048783/how-to-use-math-to-pick-a-favorite-football-team

item.title: Haight Ashbury's Free Health Clinic Still Groovy
item.description: January 22, 2017 • A series of mergers with other nonprofit clinics has transformed the 50-year-old San Francisco clinic into a $110 million health care system that provides networked care up and down California. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/01/22/510622207/haight-ashburys-free-health-clinic-middle-aged-and-still-groovy

item.title: David Linden: The Science Of Touching And Feeling
item.description: January 19, 2017 • Neuroscientist David Linden thinks that of the five senses, touch is the most overlooked, and perhaps the most important for promoting psychological health. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/20/510627341/why-is-it-important-to-be-touched

item.title: Tristram Wyatt: How Do Pheromones Really Work?
item.description: January 19, 2017 • Pheromones are mysterious compounds that can make a mammal smell more sexy--but that's not true for humans. Zoologist Tristram Wyatt says human pheremones are hard to find. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/20/510625135/how-do-pheromones-really-work

item.title: Nicole Garneau: Are There More Than Five Basic Tastes?
item.description: January 19, 2017 • Scientists have long believed we have just five tastes - salty, sweet, bitter, sour and umami (or savory). Geneticist Nicole Garneau argues we might be able to taste a sixth — fat. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/20/510621715/are-there-more-than-five-basic-tastes

item.title: 5th 'Mars Mission' Simulation Ready For Launch In Hawaii
item.description: January 19, 2017 • Starting Thursday, six people will spend eight months in a dome on Mauna Loa volcano to study what living on Mars might be like. The mission is co-sponsored by the University of Hawaii and NASA. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/19/510566033/5th-mars-mission-simulation-ready-for-launch-in-hawaii

item.title: Athlete-Turned-Trucker Works To Improve Truckers' Health
item.description: January 19, 2017 • Once an elite swimmer and a Yale grad, Siphiwe Baleka now coaches 3,000 fellow truckers on the best ways to work out, eat right and stay connected on the road. Drivers say his wellness plan works. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/01/19/508014615/athlete-turned-trucker-works-to-improve-truckers-health

item.title: Scientists Needn't Get A Patient's Consent To Study Blood Or DNA
item.description: January 18, 2017 • In its update of ethics rules aimed at protecting patients, the Obama administration decided against a provision that scientists said would hinder research. Consumer advocates aren't happy. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/01/18/510442240/scientists-neednt-get-a-patients-consent-to-study-blood-or-dna

item.title: U.S. Report Confirms 2016 Was The Hottest Year On Record
item.description: January 18, 2017 • 2016 was the warmest year on record, according to a new report by the U.S. government. This is the third year in a row that global temperatures have soared above the 20th century average. The report comes ahead of the inauguration of Donald Trump, who has at times, referred to global warming as a "hoax." http://www.npr.org/2017/01/18/510472493/u-s-report-confirms-2016-was-the-hottest-year-on-record

item.title: States Could Take Lead On Environmental Regulation Under Trump
item.description: January 18, 2017 • NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Dallas Burtraw, senior fellow with the nonpartisan think tank Resources for the Future, about what role states have traditionally played in environmental regulation, and what a decentralized approach under the Trump administration would look like. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/18/510472419/states-could-take-lead-on-environmental-regulation-under-trump

item.title: EPA Nominee Scott Pruitt Acknowledges Existence Of Climate Change
item.description: January 18, 2017 • Trump's pick to head the Environmental Protection Agency has acknowledged that human activity plays "some" role in the changing climate. In his confirmation hearing on Wednesday, Scott Pruitt said he wants to work with states to protect the environment while also encouraging economic growth. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/18/510472412/epa-nominee-scott-pruitt-acknowledges-existence-of-climate-change

item.title: What Does It Mean When Cancer Findings Can't Be Reproduced?
item.description: January 18, 2017 • Results from some key cancer studies were different when the experiments were redone in different labs. Scientists don't yet know why but say the answer could have health implications for patients. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/01/18/510304871/what-does-it-mean-when-cancer-findings-cant-be-reproduced

item.title: 2016 Was The Hottest Year Yet, Scientists Declare
item.description: January 18, 2017 • Global temperatures soared above the 20th century average last year, as the climate continues to change. It's the hottest it has been since scientists started tracking global temperatures in 1880. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/18/510405739/2016-was-the-hottest-year-yet-scientists-declare

item.title: Coronations, Coups, And Keeping Up With The Kardashians
item.description: January 17, 2017 • It's in our nature to idolize the rich and famous. But this week on Hidden Brain, we explore the other side of our nature: the part of us that wants to see the rich and powerful fall from grace. http://www.npr.org/2017/01/17/509561647/coronations-coups-and-keeping-up-with-the-kardashians
